title: Crocodile clip
text:
A crocodile clip (also alligator clip) is a sprung metal clip with long, serrated jaws which is used for creating a temporary <a href="electrical%20connection">electrical connection</a>. This simple mechanical device gets its name from the resemblance of its jaws to those of an <a href="alligator">alligator</a> or <a href="crocodile">crocodile</a>. It is used to connect an electrical cable to a battery or some other component. Functioning much like a spring-loaded <a href="clothespin">clothespin</a>, the clip's tapered, serrated jaws are forced together by a <a href="spring%20%28device%29">spring</a> to grip an object. When manufactured for electronics testing and evaluation, one jaw of the clip is typically permanently crimped or soldered to a wire, or is bent to form the inner tubular contact of a ~ female <a href="banana%20connector">banana jack</a>, enabling quick non-permanent connection between a circuit under test and laboratory equipment or to another <a href="electrical%20circuit">electrical circuit</a>. The clip is typically covered by a plastic shroud or "boot" to prevent accidental short-circuits.
Small versions, ranging in size from in length, are used in electrical <a href="laboratory">laboratory</a> work. 
Large versions of these clips, called automotive clips or battery clamps, are made of solid <a href="copper">copper</a> for low <a href="electrical%20resistance">electrical resistance</a>, and are used with thick insulated copper cables to make connections between automobile batteries. These <a href="jumper%20cable">jumper cable</a>s (a.k.a. 'jump leads') are capable of delivering hundreds of Amperes of current needed to directly power an automobile starter motor, or to transfer energy from a charged <a href="lead%E2%80%93acid%20battery">lead–acid battery</a> to a discharged one.
Specifications.
The United States Defense Logistics Agency specifies several types of electrical clips in Commercial Item Description (CID) A-A-59466. In this CID document, crocodile clips are designated type CC, alligator clips are designated types TCx, and other types of electrical clips have various other, unique designations.
Kelvin clip.
A <a href="Kelvin%20clip">Kelvin clip</a> is a special form of crocodile clip. The jaws of a Kelvin clip are insulated from each other, allowing two isolated wires to connect to a single test point. This enables <a href="four-terminal%20sensing">4-wire measurement</a> of circuits with very low resistances.
